Articles.Content:
Inmarsat-5-F3, a geostationary communications satellite, is scheduled for 11:44 UTC from Baikonur cosmodrome, on a Proton K/Briz-M rocket. This launch is important for the Proton rocket, as it has suffered from a series of recent failures, with the most recent failure in May, with the loss of a Mexican communications sat.

The stream starts at 11:30 UTC : http://www.inmarsat.com/service/global-xpress/

Edit : the stream is currently online, I think that it's the commentary that starts at 11:30
-18:24...i wonder if i can catch this just before i have to leave for the weekend. would be a nice to see a cool thing before going on a six hour drive.
What's 20 minutes to 6 hours! The entire launch takes over two hours due to the low TWR of the Briz-M stage, but the first few minutes is always the most fun!

Liftoff has happened, 2nd stage is burning well. Also, the description on the site hasn't been updated for 6 months...

Edit: 2nd stage has been jettisoned.

Edit 2: Seems Breeze-M has ignited.

Edited August 28, 2015 by SaturnianBlue
And now we get to see what looks like an extended advertisement. WHERE'S MY ROCKET LAUNCH!
Where does the first stage land at?
I'm actually not sure, its presumably somewhere in the Kazakhstan Steppes. It wouldn't land on one piece though, but I think that the engines would each land relatively intact.

Where does the first stage land at?

It doesn't "land".

http://www.thelivingmoon.com/41pegasus/02files/Space_Debris_04.html

It doesn't "land".
